conclusion: To solve the problem of finding the instantaneous value of the induced current and the average value of the induced electromotive force (emf) in a rotating rectangular wire frame.
The magnetic flux through the loop is given by Φ = B ⋅ A ⋅ cos(θ), where B is the magnetic field, A is the area of the loop, and θ is the angle between the magnetic field and the normal to the loop.
The loop is rotating with angular velocity ω. Therefore, θ(t) = ωt.
The induced emf is given by Faraday's Law: E = -dΦ/dt.
Substitute Φ = B S cos(ωt) to get E = -d/dt (B S cos(ωt)) = B S ω sin(ωt).
When the loop rotates through 60°, θ = 60° = π/3 radians.
The instantaneous induced emf is E = B S ω sin(π/3) = B S ω ⋅ √3/2.
Substitute the induced emf to get I = (B S ω √3/2)/R = √3 B S ω/(2 R).
The average emf over a time interval Δt is given by E̅ = ΔΦ/Δt.
The change in flux ΔΦ is ΔΦ = B S (cos(θ1) - cos(θ2)), where θ1 = 0 and θ2 = π/3.
Calculate ΔΦ = B S (1 - 1/2) = B S/2.
Substitute into the average emf formula to get E̅ = (B S/2)/(π/3ω) = 3 B S ω/(2π).
Instantaneous value of the induced current is I = √3 B S ω/(2 R).
Average value of the induced EMF is E̅ = 3 B S ω/(2 π).
